It should be cut from acrylic. If using cardboard the bars will not be thick enough. One could make the bars thicker but then the ratios would have to be recalculated.

title: T Slot Nut 8mm for common 6mm carriage bolts

description.text:
I have been using common carriage bolts for my CNC router table but missing a good nut to prevent the bolt rotating. This is one of my first projects after converting the router to 3D printing (RepStrap).  
The carriage bolts can be found in many hardware stores in buckets at a low price.

Print using your 3D printer in ABS for high strength.  
The part is optimized for low plastic usage.

title: The Darth Vader and Storm Trooper Shakers are now TWISTED!

description.text:
I have finally gotten around to making my salt shakers
with a twist top lid, instead of a sliding lid.

Both the lids were a little tight at first, but I carefully
twisted each one on and off a few times, and they
soon settled into place.

The Storm Trooper is 2" in diameter and 1.75" tall.
Darth Vader is 2.25" in diameter and 2" tall.

The bottoms print without support. I used one small
manual support in the middle of the holes to print
the top.

Enjoy!

If you are like me, you end up with lots of little pieces of filament on your work table.  This object allow you to turn a common zip lock bag into a table edge trash bag.  Its use is not limited to 3D printing setups, but with all the little scraps you get it is particularly useful.  Since it sits under the edge of the table, you don't have to pick up the small pieces of filament, you can just brush them off the table into the bag.

You really need to measure your table thickness and use the customizer to get this to work. Put your table thickness in the customizer to get the correct gap size to fit your table. Generate the STL and print out two of them. You don't need much infill since the large parts don't really support any weight. You don't need to mirror them since the wide part is hidden under the table. You probably want to use ABS to get the springiness needed for a good fit on the table edge. If it is out a little to wobbly, decrease the gap a little bit. These print fast with no support needed and don't need much filament so you may want to experiment with the gap to get it to work perfectly. When I printed two I didn't need any cooling.
I'm currently using a sandwich bag. I suspect it will work with other size zip top bags depending on your volume needs. When attaching the zip top bag, fold it over so the zipper gets pushed up into the groove. This will create the needed thickness to keep it from sliding out. Put a holder on each end of the bag and slide it onto your table. You can then scrape your waste right into the bag. Look how clean my table is now!
I just started using this so I may adjust it as time goes on. It doesn't clamp on super strongly, but it appears to be enough so far. I want the design to be as simple to print as possible with no unprintable parts.

comments.text: What type of bag do you use?  Hefty slider bag's don't fit this design.  I'll see if I can alter the SCAD file to allow a small hole at the end of the clip to allow the plastic end to go into.
comments.author: RSkarl

comments.text: That is a Ziploc brand sandwich bag.  I hadn't thought about slider bags.  If I recall, I think you can pry off the slider so it reverts back to a nonslider version.  The SCAD file is very simple though I suspect you won't have any trouble modifying it.
comments.author: RSkarl

Thought this would be a good test thing to make and publish. Its a discrete and simple LED mount. It uses standard thru hole LED's in series, and attaches to the front of the printer where the stock cooler goes. It is wired in parallel with the extruder cooling fan.

  • 2- #6 1/2" Machine Screws.
  • 4- 5mm Clear or difused white LED
  • 33 ohm resistor
  • Any translucent film to go behind the rhino. (I used 3m tape which was perfect)
  • HOT GLUE

The wider the angle the better for the LED's I used what I had laying around. The angle was way to narrow so i sanded the rounded part down which worked pretty good.

Installation:

Pretty straight forward, i punched the lights into a piece of paper to help me solder them in and get the polarity correct. Although after you fit two together I found it easier to solder them in place on the print.

Side note:
The cooler I am now using is the Ciii Cooler - Rear mounted cooler for Wanhao Duplicator i3 https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2004629. But the Cobra cooler works aswell. Any rear mounted cooler will work that doesnt use the front screws where the original cooling fan goes.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used Black Hatchbox ABS.

title: Tinkerlight Desk Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the desk lamp design for the Tinkerlight system. It requires the lamp hardware kit.
Full details of the system are at:

http://robot50.net/projects/tinkerlight/

I have a batch of hardware kits for sale on ebay for $5 each: http://www.ebay.com/itm/-/152286884727?.

You will also need your own USB power source.

The desk lamp has a spare design with an H base and an arm that can extend from about 9 inches of total lamp height to about 12 inches. The shade pivots and the base includes two cord keepers. The spot lens in the kit may optionally be mounted for a tighter pool of light.

The light source supplied with the kit is a neutral white (4000-4500k) LED that consumes 2.25 watts (450ma at 5 volts).

The desk lamp parts will print on most printers without supports and a 6x6x6 build platform. ABS is recommended for its higher heat resistance but the lamp will work with PLA.

title: Direct-drive hinged extruder for E3D/J-Head hot-end (Prusa i3)

description.text:
Here is my attempt at designing an extruder for my Prusa i3. I took some inspiration from different designs to try to make an extruder which is easy to print, compact, easy to clean and has tight guides for the filament (to be able to use flexible materials). I made a couple of test prints with it and it seems to work fine so far. I haven't tested any challenging materials yet, just PLA. Here are the components:
  • E3D all metal hot end for 1.75mm filament. It mounts like a J-Head so a J-Head should fit as well.
  • NEMA17 stepper motor. I am using a 40mm motor but any NEMA17 should work. The back of the motor is mounted on the X carriage and all the extruder parts are mounted to the front of the motor.
  • Mk8 Drive Gear. The Idler and filament guide are very tight around the Mk8 gear so other gears will probably not fit without modifications.
  • EDIT: The design is now for a 5x10x4 ball bearing and not the initial Yoyo ball bearing (It is a 5x11x5 bearing grooved to 10mm in the center) The groove helps guide the filament but it should also work with a flat 5x10x4, 5x10x5 or 5x11x5 bearing.
  • 50mm centrifugal fan (5015S 12V 50x15mm)
  • A Spring. I am using one from an IKEA PRESSA clothespin.
  • Some M3 and M4 screws and nuts.
    • EDIT - Version 1.1:
    After a bit of testing, the grooved bearing worked fine with PLA and Nylon but not with Flexibel PolyEster so I switched to a flat 5x10x4 bearing. I improved a bit the "idler arm" to make it able to squeeze the filament a bit further and also made it slightly stronger. I was able to make a nice flexible print with this new setup. Stay tuned :-) EDIT - Version 1.2:
    Here is a new version. This is now designed specifically for a 5x10x4 (or 5x10x5) ball bearing and it includes an even tighter filament guide. I had some issues printing flexible polyester with the previous version, this one works better. I have also tested with PLA, Nylon and PET without problems so far. Here is a video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=80q71dtGmuk I have also uploaded the sources made with LibreCAD and OpenSCAD so you can customize it to your needs. Make sure you upload the remixes! :-) EDIT - Better fan duct:
    Here is a slightly more advanced fan duct which help distribute some airflow around the nozzle: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:151555 EDIT - Two can fit on a 80mm carriage!
    Here is a video of my dual extrusion system: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ca-XfL2IUWs
Just drop a comment if you need me to provide some instructions on how to assemble :-)

comments.text: I've printed this extruder and, using a remix, mounted it to my Makerfarm Prusa i3v with an E3D-v6. It pushes plastic into the hotend just fine, but when it does the nozzle moves towards the inside of the printer (away from you if you were standing in front of the printer). Surely the movement would cause issues with prints. It's almost as if the opening on the extruder base is too large for the top of the E3D-v6, thus it's not holding it still and allowing it to wobble when plastic is pushed down into the nozzle.

comments.text:
To note: You said "I'm using a 40mm motor but any NEMA17 should work".
You may not know but NEMA refers to an American size convention. All motors with a face of 43*43 are NEMA17. The torque is independent (to the extent of physical laws).
comments.author: AcrimoniousMirth

comments.text: Any NEMA17 will work in terms of mounting the extruder to it, that is because all NEMA17 have the same front "footprint". As far as which will have enough torque, I cannot say anything, shorter motors will typically tend to have less torque than longer ones but a longer one is going to be heavier (which is not good). A way to control the torque is also to adjust the current for the motor. More current will give more torque but that will make the motor heat up more  (which is not good)... All I can say is that the 40mm one I linked works fine and remains cold to the touch even after hours of printing. Cheers, Franck.

comments.author: janwynen

comments.text: Hello! There could be many reasons for this. It could be the a problem with the hot-end getting "jammed" either because the temperature is too low and makes the filament hard to extrude or because there is some "burned filament" left in the hot-end (temperature too hot or low quality filament). Typically with the E3D hot end and decent filament there is not much issues. You can test it by extruding filament manually and checking that it is not too hard to push and that the extrusion is clean. The other possible  cause is that the tension of the spring needs to be adjusted. Too much are too little tension can cause the gear to slip and grind into the filament. Especially it you are using high printing speeds and/or high retract speed. Also check that the hinge/spring action is smooth, it is also important so that the pressure on the filament is consistent. Good luck! Franck
comments.author: janwynen

comments.text: Hi, i love this design however when i print the extruder v1.2 all the holes sizes / nut traps come out to small, i can get round this by drilling however the inset for the j-head also prints to small and doesnt fit, have you had similar issues? i tried to edit the settings using openscad but it only exports the idler and doesnt show the extruder itself, and suggestions?
comments.author: 3DPartsUK

comments.text: Hello, I have not had that problem but the callibration of you printer is probably different than mine, you could try to scale up the whole part if all the dimensions are too small. If only the "holes" are too small you could try calibrating your extrusion, it typically means that too much material is being extruded. If you want to export the different parts from the source, there are different modules in the openscad script, you have to uncomment the ones you want to export at the bottom of the file. Cheers! Franck

If this would happend I had thought about using a bolt instead of the plastic shaft but I also had another idea which was to keep the plastic shaft and add a "cap" on top of the idler in order to support the shaft and keep the bearing in the right place. comments.text: The fan on the e3d should keep the PLA on the extruder from melting, even at extreme temperatures. I've comfortably held the top of mine while running the nozzle at 300C. You should be fine.

title: Tinkerlight Utility Light
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the utility light design for the Tinkerlight system. It requires the lamp hardware kit.
Full details of the system are at:

http://robot50.net/projects/tinkerlight/

The lamp hardware kit can be purchased for $5 on ebay at: http://www.ebay.com/itm/-/152286884727?

You will also need your own USB power source.

The utility light is intended to be mounted on a flat surface with small bolts, screws, or double-stick tape. It pivots in one direction and includes two cord keepers and bolt/screw holes around the base. The shade provides minimal eye protection from the very bright LED so this design should always be used with the lens mounted.

The light source supplied with the kit is a neutral white (4000-4500k) LED that consumes 2.25 watts (450ma at 5 volts).

The utility light will print on most printers without supports and a 6x6x6 build platform. ABS is recommended for its higher heat resistance but the lamp will work with PLA.

remixed_from.author: GarageBay9
remixed_from.title: Open WarHex - modular, scenic 3D Hex terrain project

description.text:
Want to save some plastic? Need to (or just feel like) covering a sizable table with WarHex, but 6ft x 8ft coverage of the big 12 hex fields at full height are a lot to store just to fill out ground level? Want a flat map where you can still use module rings? Playing on a hex-printed gaming map where you want to show terrain templates?

Have we got a solution for you!

These are the single, double, triple, seven, and twelve hex core pieces, shortened to a flat-bottomed plate that can be used to quickly and easily build out most of a map on a large table, with reduced space and material use. They don't stack on top of other hexes, but if the only thing under them is the table or a gaming mat, it's a feature. : )

Note: these are NOT compatible with the "Testbed" experimental branch. These use the core set central hex contours. Testbed branch rings will not seat on these.

original work!

Print if you wish. It works as is, but has not been tested against a vintage Digicomp I.
Testing will occur over the next couple of months.

This is a work in progress of a 3d printed recreation of the DIgicomp I, a three-bit computer from the 60's. Thanks to the members of the FriendsOfDigiComp Yahoo group for their help, and their preservation of details about this device, including drawings, photos and manuals. And of course, thanks to ESR, for their genius in creating this product way back when...

The intent of this thingy is to provide a source for those who want to print there own, or to replace missing parts for a vintage device. We'll see if this all works out.

I've finally obtained a DC I off Ebay and am currently updating parts. So far, they're very close. I'll post when complete.

OTHER SOURCES YOU SHOULD KNOW ABOUT:

Looking for a DC I that you don't have to print? Concerned about the cost to print? A wonderful, fully functional recreation of the DC I in card-stock is available from MindsOnToys: http://www.mindsontoys.com/kits.htm

Looking for a DC II ? EvilMadScientist has a beautiful recreation in wood. http://shop.evilmadscientist.com/productsmenu/tinykitlist/375-dcii

And of course, there's a DC II app for IOS devices, if I may tout my own product.
https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/virtual-dc-ii/id668402874?ls=1&mt=8

Thanks !

modified base, with two opposite rounded corners for easier printing
Qty-2 Color=Red End-piece or End-piece reinforced

Qty-3 Color=Red Readout Tab or (in white) readout tab with raised numbers
Qty-3 Color=Red Readout Connector (or use short sections of drinking straw)

Qty-1-2 Color=Red Double Slider - used in certain calculations

Qty-1 Color White Reset Clock
Qty-1 Color White Set-Clear Clock
Qty-1 Color White Rod Bearing Plate
Qty-1 Any Color - wire template
Qty-6 Any Color - base Clips

Additionally:
0.055 music wire for rods
0.061 music wire for crank
number 10 rubber bands, Qty- 6

Bend 12 logic rods using the 0.55 music wire
Bend 1 crank using the 0.061 music wire.
Bend a length of wire and bend a 90 degree angle in the end to act as the pin.

Optionally:
Rubber Band Pulleys - qty 6 - my rubber bands keep popping of the top of the logic rods. (Somehow that sounds like it should be censored) So I'd have to take the top plate off, reattach the rubber bands, and put the top plate back on. Maybe I'm doing something wrong, but this got old quickly. Print the rubber band pulleys and pop one onto the top of the logic rods. Put the rubber band in the groove provided. Haven't lost a rubber band since !

BENDING INSTRUCTIONS:.
Print out the wire template, and us hand tools such as those shown in the 'wire bending tools photo'. It's tough work, but after making 12 of them, you'll have it mastered. Be sure that after bending the rod, if very close to matching the template. Try to make squarish corners, especially on top to help the rubber bands stay on. Lay the rod on the table, and make sure it lay's flat all the way from the top to the bottom, or it will cause problems later. With a nod to Norm, be sure to wear (these) safety glasses, and gloves, as music wire can split into sharp shards. Work in an open area, so the wire doesn't poke your mother-in-law or the cat in the eye. Initially, I tried cutting the wires to length but found it way easier to keep the wire longer, giving more bending leverage. Besides the printed wire template, I used a heavy set of needle nose pliers, lineman's pliers, and a mini bolt cutter for cutting the music wire. Yes, you can cut it with the lineman's plier's but it's much easier with the bolt cutter. I used http://www.amazon.com/Knipex-7101200-8-Inch-Action-Mini-Bolt/dp/B000SOSC4Y/ref=sr_1_11?s=power-hand-tools&ie=UTF8&qid=1461523354&sr=1-11&keywords=KNIPEX which I picked up at Menards.

BUILD TIPS:

1) It's important to carefully remove any overprint or schmutz. I tend to print tight on the first layer to make sure it sticks to the print bed. This causes the plastic to spread out on the first layer. This should be cleaned out especially where there is contact with other parts of the device. For instance, one problem was the slot in the front of the sliders must allow a rod to move smoothly into and out of the slot. If the rods catch in the slot the device will not function. Also on each horizontal plate, ensure the overprint is cleaned out in the slot the pin goes through. Each plate must move smoothly past the pin to their full extent without catching.

2) The rod shape has little tolerance. If the horizontal sections of a rod are too long (even slightly), the rod may not move into the correct place, especially with the clock rods.

3) At the top of the rods, where the end goes through the the rod bearing plate, the tail end of the rod may be too long and catch on the sliders. Trim off a bit of the end of the wire if necessary.

4) The crank hole in the base is intentionally tight/undersized (depending on print). It's critical that the crank does not wobble, so carefully ream out the hole just until the crank fits. A tight fit is preferred. If the crank wobbles around, the reliability or function of the device will be affected.

Progress notes:

UPDATE 5/20/16

Continuing to work on documentation at http://www.someoldguycoding.com/projects/digicomp-i/.
Device passes the check out problem from the original manual after a little tweaking.

Once documentation is complete, parts will be shipped to tester to compare against a vintage DCI. If there issues updates will be made

Thanks for your time and interest
mark-

comments.text:
very very nice, was looking for something like this.
how did you paint the wood?
did you use a sponge or did you stipple with a brush?
comments.author: KagBB

comments.text: For the wood, I dry brush everything using craft paints.   I started with the pieces assembled and spray painted matte black ( the $1 cans of black spray paint from Home Depot). I first dry bushed on some Burnt Umber (Americana), then dry brushed on some Cocca (Americana), and then dry brushed on some Fawn (Americana).
comments.author: KagBB

comments.text:
Have you got any tips for printing the Bottles or Tankards? Mine are turning out... less than perfect. I'm printing at 0.1mm layers and going at 20mm/s with no infill, I tried with 15% infill and it was worse.
I've got the bars printing beautifully though so thank you very much!
comments.author: sirjimjam

comments.text: When I print bottles and tankards, I print no less than about 20 at a time.  I bunch them close enough together to get one big skirt around them.  I think the most important thing it making sure that each layer has enough time to cool.   I don't use a heated build plate when I print them.   My default speed is set between 80-90mm/sec and my infill is 13% (though these are so small I doubt it actually adds infill.  I rarely change my settings, so if it it looks like the parts are not getting enough time to cool, I just keep adding parts until they come out.  For me, the magic number is about 20+ bottles or tankards at a time.  Hope that helps.
comments.author: sirjimjam

comments.text: Ahh that makes sense now, once I'm done printing the corner of this bar I'll make sure the patrons have something to drink!
comments.author: Curufin

comments.text: I was looking for exactly these items and this was the holy grail. Thank you.

comments.text: Thanks!  If you look at my other designs, you will find the bar.  The bartender is a miniature from Reaper.
comments.author: zognogin

comments.text: Awesome, thank again for making these
comments.author: Curufin

comments.text: Printing this stuff all out now :)  Any tips on painting bottles and tankards?  I imagine there is a base coat then another color for highlights?  And I am assuming there is a special technique when highlighting tankards and wine bottles to make them look really shiny?  They look so wonderful in your photos :)  Got most everything printed out now.. just need to print the bottles and tankards.
comments.author: JenniferG

comments.text: I base coat everything I print in cheap matte black spray paint.  The Tankards are just one coat of Metallic grey or silver.  The bottles are a coat of green and then a coat of gloss varnish after it is dry.
comments.author: JenniferG

comments.text: Wow, so simple thank you!  What kind of gloss varnish do you use?  I have some wood varnish here.
comments.author: Curufin

comments.text: Really any kind of Gloss clear varnish will do.  I like Polycrylic because it is water soluble, but I think I used something called Game Color, because it was in front of me at the time.  It is all just degrees of the same thing.
comments.author: JenniferG

comments.text: How do you simplify the painting of the bottles and tankards?  I am holding the bottles with my finger tips and having to paint half, then let dry and do other half.. Same for the gloss coat.
comments.author: Curufin

comments.text: No rafts.  Take some masking tape, the wider the better.  If you dont have 2" or 4" wide masking tape overlap some thinner strips to make a wider piece.   Stick down all of you tankards on one piece and all the bottles on a separate piece of tape.
comments.author: JenniferG

comments.text: Very clever McGyver :)  I figured you had to use spray paint by the way :)  By any chance, could you share which sprays you use for silver and green?  Thank you :)  Also I imagine you sprayed on the clear gloss as well ?
comments.author: Curufin

comments.text: No, only the base coat (matte black) was spray painted.  Everything else was painted with craft paints and bushes, including the gloss coat.    The silver was just a metallic grey (maybe pewter?).  The green was just a darkish green (maybe forest green?)  It's hard to say, I mix almost all of my colors to get what I want.   Browns are the only paint I have a variety of.
comments.author: JenniferG

title: Printable Parametric VESA 75/100 Adaptor for Mounting ITX Cases Etc.

description.text:
I recently purchased a M350 Universal Mini-ITX enclosure to hold a compact workstation for 3D rendering purposes. As I am tight for space, the case had to be as small as possible and preferably mount to my 19' widescreen monitor. The M350 seemed to fit the bill, but it was only after I purchased it that I thought to check the mounting holes on my monitor... Doh, there is more than one VESA standard and my monitor and case did not match. So I have created a printable adaptor that is as parametric as I can make it. As well as having variables for the key attributes you may need to change such as mounting hole sizes and the height of the adaptor, their are also 3 different styles of mounting plate you can generate using the scad file.

  • Cross. The mounts are held in place by two crossed beams

  • Outer Ring. The mounts are contained within a ring which has optional oval cut-outs

  • Full Strength. (Photos) This has both the outer ring and internal cross members for full support. I am no engineer, but I am pretty sure this is the strongest option of the three.
    • There is also an option to switch between generating the mounting plate and a much smaller calibration piece. Although designed to mount an ITX case to a VESA75 equiped monitor, I am sure that this design can be used for other purposes as well. Hence the amount of adjustment possible via Openscad. I printed mine in PLA and it seems strong enough to hold my ITX case and electronics.

Download the scad file and open in OpenScad. Change the test_piece variable to true to allow you to calibrate the piece. Set your variables to whatever sizes you think work best on your own printer. Export the test piece as an STL and try printing it. The test piece is one corner of the mounting adaptor, you can test fit it to the monitor that you are going to be using. If you are happy with the test piece go back to Openscad and set test_piece=false. Now choose set the options that you want for the adaptor. As well as changing the style of the adaptor you can tweak other variables to make the adaptor stronger or lighter. I have tried to comment everything as clearly as possible. If in doubt, try changing things a bit and see the effect it has on the adaptor. You can also decide what kind of mounting holes that you would like for both the 75mm spaced and 100mm spaced holes independently of each other. There are options for either a trapped nut or a recessed screw and washer. Note that the size of the mounts is adjusted by both the m4_washer_diameter and mount_chunkiness variables so even if you are using trapped nut mounting holes throughout, you will probably still need to play with this variable. Available Variables
test_piece
vesa_75_nut
vesa_100_nut
outer_ring_option
center_piece_option
outer_ring_cutouts_option
plate_height
m4_thread_diameter
m4_nut_diameter
m4_washer_diameter
m4_head_depth
mount_chunkiness
cutout_width
cutout_length
cutout_gap Print with your preferred settings. I printed mine with 3 outer layers and 35% infill. This seems dureable enough with my ITX case YMMV. Insert the nuts and bolts that you wish and attach the devices that you wish to use with the adaptor.

description.text:
Needed to cover the live wires of the printer but could not find exactly the correct item here so designed one for myself to the exact dimensions of my PSU - comes with my printer - Geeetech Full Metal Aluminium Prusa i3X. Also needed clamps to fix it to the 6mm Alu frame so made those as well.

From the pix you can see that the PSU has no fixing holes on 2 sides so makes it difficult to fix the cover. It is fixed with one self threaded screw and one ziptie as shown.

The clamps fit over the PSU and are a tight fit. Then they are fixed to the frame and tightened in place with an M3 screw in the hole provided.

Printer:

Geeetech Full Metal Aluminum

Rafts:

No

Yes

0.2

20%

Notes:

Tried to avoid supports as much as possible while reducing plastic. Used Cura with LINE infill for easy removal.

Printed in PLA @ 200/55 with gluestick & cheap hairspray for adherence.
On my heated bed with the gluestick & hairspray, I had a tough time removing the pieces. Stuck like crazy.

I wanted to DIY dual extrusion and wanted the new style clamp. So I drew up this one based on the Ultimaker v1 laser cut patterns and Bertho's extruder, and adapted for components more readily available in the US.

Ultimaker v.2 Drive Replica What it is, what it isn't
This is an extruder drive design, based on the Ultimaker extruder drive and Bertho's extruder upgrade. It is NOT the lasercut pattern for the original Ultimaker v2 drive, which is closed source. It is not intended to be part compatible with either design. I wanted to DIY dual extrusion and wanted the new style clamp, so I drew up this one based on the Ultimaker v1 laser cut patterns, and adapted for components more readily available in the US. BOM Material
1/8" (~3mm) plywood
3mm delrin
printed block Hardware
1" x .3" x 60 lb/in spring (http://www.mcmaster.com/#9573k11/)
1/8"ID, 5/16"OD, 9/64"W bearing (http://www.mcmaster.com/#57155k366) Screws
M3x20mm (5ct)
M3x12mm (4ct)
M3x30mm (1ct)
M3 locknut (3ct)
M3 hexnut (7ct)
M3 washer (2ct)
M4 washer (1ct) Notes
  • YMMV on spring choice. This design has about 20mm max installed spring length. The spring I used has about 8kgf at 17mm length, where Bertho's design uses 3.4kgf.
  • When laser cutting the plywood, use raster at high power to route out the space for the bearing and wheel. Test cut a few squares to ~.3mm depth
  • Print the block with high internal fill as it is a structural part. Use the 12mm width block if you have metric 4mm plywood instead of 1/8" plywood.

author: BenRockhold

description.text: made for a friend
scale to your hearts content

For starts this is my first upload so any feedback is appreciated (as long as it is constructive). I am still in High School and I am trying to familiarize myself to the fullest with 3D Modeling. I hope to eventually get a job in Modeling and Drafting for prototyping and such.

I was stumbling around online for ideas to draft up and eventually print on schools Makerbot. I eventually tried to make a Rack and Pinion, but I never uploaded nor printed it. Then I stumbled upon the reuleaux triangle.

The thing that intrigued me about the reuleaux triangle is that when it is encased in a pair of parallel, no matter their orientation against the shape, the thing is the same width! So I saw an animation of how it can be offset on an axle and used as a cam to convert rotational movement into reciprocating linear movement on 507 Movements. It is # 91 on their list.

http://507movements.com/mm_091.html

As I was initially drawing it I suddenly realized that I could not print it in place so I had to component-ize and separate each individual part. Then I had to modify the main frame so it could be assembled post print.

There will probably have to be some sanding and fitting done as I do not think I made the tolerances forgiving enough, however the top plate should fit tight and be semi-permanent. Pictures to come!.

P.S. If you are wondering about the file names, trinkets like this are referred to as Bull [email protected]# Grinders around here.

UPDATE:

It Seems as though there is an issue with some of the ends not having surfaces on the Main Frame. Updates to come shortly!
The fixed file has been uploaded, and replaced the damaged one. I changed the elevation of the center rail of the main frame as well to make more of the cam tough the reciprocator. Also I changed the side beams so they stretch all of the way down, as I realized mid print that the Makerbot software did not load any supports under them. This is a long way to bridge, especially printing at the size I am (+650%)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

See below

Notes:

When loading the parts into the Makerbot Slicer, I had to blow them up by at least 600% of the original size. I am not sure how to fix this, it may have something to do with how I exported the .STL files from sketchup (I use an extension to export the .STL file rather than buying a pro license). If you have any tips, please by all means leave it in the comments.

infill:
I did 10% for the main frame and knob

description.text:
Update 4/26/16: I had the cover photo with the dial mounted upside down. I've removed it for now and will add the correct picture. The "Handle", the long thin part, faces up and acts as a level to help easily detach and attach to the xrods with very minimal force. This may be able to be shortend, but really doesn't add more than a few min to the print and as is worth it in my opinion.

I liked the way http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:944632 mounted to the xrod and came of easily but it didn't fit my round digital dial gauge. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1445744/ fit the dial, but I didn't like the tension it put on the xrods

title: Square test pattern for leveling troubleshooting

description.text:
(Feedback appreciated!!!)
A simple test to use for troubleshooting. The goal is to have a common test pattern for everyone so that diagnosis of adjustments can be easier to identify and correct than a typical troubleshooting web page with many different images of unknown models, which may lead to confusing or inaccurate interpretations.

My monoprice maker select printer claims to take 10 minutes to print and would use 0.17 meters (< 1gram) of filament.

I'm new to 3d printing and I'm having some difficulties leveling the bed. Halfway through this print, it will mess up - it will detach/loosen from the surface and not finish. Also, the first layer is inconsistent in volume, and will initially fail to extrude for appr. the first 5cm.

My thinking is that a piece of paper used to measure the extruder distance is giving me some inaccurate results during the standard bed level procedure. So by printing a large square, and using it as a test for others, a common baseline could be used in describing the test results.

I added about a 1.5mm high extension to each of the four corners so that it would reveal how well the printer would extrude/retract in small amounts at specific points far apart. It would possibly indicate an issue.

As I encounter more issues in the future, I can continue to improve and expand upon this basic model to include further tests.

Printer:

Wanhao/Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

comments.text: You are using the wrong firmware if you are getting what you are describing.  There is no reason to over extrude or under extrude if the programming is correct.   Printer is doing what the programming is telling it.  By default the monoprice maker, even in the manual it says to flash your drive with marlin code.  Yet,  when you select the printer they say to use reprap code.   Why not marlin?  I am using the 3.0x version now in spite what Monoprice has told me to keep using their Cura 15.x,  with marlin code and I solved my problem which was similar to yours for almost 6 months.

author: itchyfinger

description.text:
I have started a mission to create a 3d printed version of as many tools as possible. My goal isn't really to make anything particularity useful, but to improve my skills at CAD, design and printing.

So far i just have a mallet, but I'll keep adding them as I make them.

Update: 11 April 2016
Reworked the mallet, made the handle much more handle-like, and added a slot and wedge to the top of the mallet to keep the head on the handle. Will get real pictures up soon. Started working on my second design, a modular pocket-hole jig. May take me a couple days to get it done.

Update: 12 April 2016
Got the rough version of the Pocket Hole Jig completed. It has removable inserts that allow you to use it with different sized drill bits, I can make any size you want, if you have any special requests, then just comment. The jig has two sets of "Wings" the front set will center you on a 2x4 or a 1x4. If you line up the left side, then the right side of the back wings, then you will make two evenly spaced holes on the 1/3rd line and the 2/3rd lines.You will destroy the inserts, so you may just want to print two or three at a time. I have not tested this print, or the mallet yet. My printer is down for a couple days, once i have it back up i will adjust the pocket-hole-jig and the mallet as needed, and i will also get real pictures up. If you have any feedback just comment below and I'll try to acomodate any changes i can. I have decided that my next project will be an angle-finder (or something close)

Update: 20 April 2016
Got my printer up and running, tested the mallet, unfortunately i found a few issues. I had a really bad allowance issue with the hole in the hammer, and the handle-head proportions were way off. I fixed these issues and uploaded a new version. I will re-print tonight and then hopefully get real pictures up. When i was printing i found that PLA felt better than ABS since PLA is about 25% more dense than the ABS. I also found that the handle prints best standing up on end, rather than on its side.

Update: 15 September 2016
I re-did the mallet to be quite a bit more practical. Print it with as few supports as possible but a heavy infill. The head is hollow, if there are too many supports inside the head, use something like a long nail to knock out as many as you can through the hole, then fill the head with sand or BBs. once the head is full you can fill the hole with hot glue, or a 3/8ths bolt

title: Bosch IXO III Electric Screwdriver (13mm Drill Chuck Adapter)

description.text:
Bosch IXO III Electric Screwdriver (13mm Drill Chuck Adapter)

You can print in either PLA or Nylon, I recommend Nylon but PLA will work, the fit is very tight and you'll might use a Hammer to get it fixed into the Chuck assembly, you might need to use the Screwdriver torque to get it through, this is meant to be a removable system hence it won't be very secure for heavy applications.

I used a very big chuck which is linked for reference - http://www.amazon.in/Hitachi-401506-Drill-Chuck/dp/B00SYPBBMY?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00

title: Real Drone landing gear!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is the first version of my Real Drone Landing gear.

all the items i have seen for drones look to isolate the vibrations and impackt locally on a per system basis, this however while doing nothing for vibration does soften the impact from new fliers and otherwise harsh crash landings.

the design uses a single Traxxas tmaxx shock per lander and is fully foldable with a servo. Since this is the first design it is no where near perfect and i have currently abandoned it for a larger better version seeing as my drone will weigh about 45 lbs.

ive included the last revision blenderfile. its a mess but all the parts are there for your pleasure. (maybe not hers XD) prototype worked but i needed bigger and better more customizable. stay tuned for version 2

blender...

the foot design i am proud of it reminds me of early 90's mechanized war suits (mechs) so basically to assemble attach ankle joint of the foot with a 4 mm bolt to the truss, then pop the top of the truss into the servo bracket, install servo with two screws and then use servo horn screw to lock down the truss to the servo. then un bolt your drone motor and apply to underside of arm using langer 3mm hardware. works on most drones that use arms with X pattern to attach motors from the bottom :)

title: Armattan Acro Pod Hawkeye VTX Mount

description.text:
I made this mount to fit in the notches at the back edge of the Armattan Acro pod. The slots are intended to hold a carbon plate and the LED array that they sell with it. I was running a Kiss FC, which doesn't support programable LEDs, so I thought Id make something to fit this instead. Print both files, it is 2 parts. The back has the grove for the sma pigtail and hole at the bottom for wires. can only go one way because the notches are slightly offset.

Gives clean access to dip switches.

The pigtail end goes up, and the pigtail can be looped through the small hole to the left, and straight down, to then be mounted in the SMA bulk heads behind the pod.

I take off the connectors on the VTX and direct solder. I have not tested with the connector on, so I dont know if it will fit. Also, the hole for wires is all the way to one side for this reason.

description.text:
UPDATE October 28, 2013: I've uploaded an improved version (Upper Filament Guide 2) that makes the hole a little smaller, and moves it a little closer to the stepper motor. This results in much improved reliability.  
I noticed recently that my MendelMax 2.0 was squeaking whenever the filament was being retracted or re-engaged during printing. When I looked closer, I noticed that the upper filament guide that came with my printer was flexing up and down at the same time. The delamination was obvious (black part in photo) once I removed it from the printer. Not good.  
After printing a replacement part and discovering it also squeaked, I designed a new part. This has a thinner hole that is larger, so there is less friction between the filament and the guide. The new one works perfectly.

title: Printed Windup Car, No Assembly Required, for 3D Systems PJ4500 Printer

description.text:
A video of the windup car in action: https://youtu.be/4dcH0_db01o

This is a windup car which demonstrates 3 different types of printed-spring mechanisms:

  • A large spiral mainspring (which stores the energy that makes the car go)
  • A spring-loaded rotary ratchet mechanism (which allows the car to continue "gliding" once the mainspring has fully unwound)
  • A front bumper mounted with a linear spring

I designed this 1 or 2 years ago to demonstrate some of the awesome stuff that the 3D Systems ProJet 4500 can do with thin, flexible features. It requires no assembly, and can be printed in full color if you wish.

Perhaps it would also work on an SLS printer? I'd be very curious to find out!

Enjoy! If you want the SLDPRT file to tinker with, shoot me a message.

This design relies on the use of thin features to create the springs,and these will require extra cure time. After you print the windup car, let it sit in the printer for 24 hours before you depowder and remove it. The springs need the additional time to cure in their resting positions before they are removed from the support of the uncured powder.

After that, make sure to depowder the clearance space between the axels and their bearings.

For post-processing, I recommend leaving the car as is. In a pinch though, I think you could use the low-temperature soy wax process to make the colors pop. I believe that process is outlined in the 3D Systems best practices document for the printer. Beware, the heat of the process might cause the springs to "droop" a bit.

title: PTFE guide tube holder for Wanhao Duplicator i3

description.text:
I needed a solid guide tube holder for my Wanhao Duplicator i3 and all the other designs here weren't up to par.

The design is based on the assumption that you don't have your filament spool mounted on top of the printer but somewhere else instead. In my case, I have several spools on a shelf above. Ergo, it doesn't extend too far back. It's designed for 4mm OD tubes.

If you want to use this holder you have to tap the M3-hole and you will also need an appropriate length M3 screw (why not 10mm). Insert the PTFE tube and tension the screw just enough so that the guide tube doesn't move - but also doesn't deform.

Printer:

Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

No

0.2

50%

Notes:

Triangular-pattern infill for rigidity.

Remixed in inkercad
A simple, removeable replacement for the stock Ultimaker reel mount that can handle all sorts of reel sizes and generates less friction.

You will need a short length of 1/2" ID PVC pipe, cut to the width of your widest reel + 25mm (1"). Slightly chamfering the ends will make assembly a bit easier.  
Insert the pipe into the base, and use the through holes in the base as guides to drill #32 holes in the PVC. This will allow you to use a 1.25" #4 bolt and nut to lock the pipe into the base (or remove it for transport).  
Place the tip on the  floor with the tapered side up, and push the other end of the pipe into it. It will be a very tight fit.  
Remove the stock Ultimaker reel mount and unscrew the mount plate. Replace the plate with your new base and bolt it securely using the original bolts.  
Insert the pipe, line up the holes, insert the #4 bolt and tighten it up. All done!  
Suggested printing parameters: 1mm top/bottom, 3mm wall, 20% infill.

print_settings.Notes:: Used 0,4mm nozzle with 2 perimeters and 0.6mm top/bottom.

title: Universal Belted Extruder - Bowden and Direct

description.text:
No longer working on this extruder

I have put this work to a stop and designed a new much simpler extruder for 1.75mm filament. I'll change it a bit to 3mm if people want it: Belted Extruder V2. for 1.75mm Bowden

Beta Testing

This Universal Belted Extruder is put here in Beta testing mode!

Main features

  • Belted Extruder
  • Works for Direct-drive and Bowden.- Work in progress
  • Bowden input available to get filament smoothly to the filament-bit.
  • Nema 17 or Nema 17 Pancake recommended.
  • Multiple belt lengths can be used 172-GT2 to 188-GT2. - you need to use a small idler for the 188-GT2 belt.
  • Strictly using Aluminium gears for higher precision and durability

Recommended Pulleys used and gearing

  • For 60-GT2 and 16-GT2 pulleys the ration is 1:3,75
  • For 60-GT2 and 20-GT2 pulleys the ratio is 1:3

Known/planned to make missing features

  • Only the E3D slotted adapter is finished
  • Adapter for standard Bowdne Push-in adapter with thread is almost here
  • Might need a Mount adapter for direct-drives, but they should be easy to make

As everyone else I have been looking at multiple Extruders and tried several, but what really bugged me was how they all sort of locked me into it.. I have 3 printers and tinker a lot, and have been missing something more... Universal

Universal Belted Extruder

  • Firstly it is using a belt to drive it instead of 2 gears grinding together. It should make it more accurate and less noisy.
  • You can use it as a Bowden-Extruder or Direct-Extruder by selecting the adapter matching your setup! - Work in progress
  • You can use the Bowden-fitting of your choice: Screw in push-fitting, Ultimaker push-fittng or the E3Ds Bowden Groove Mount. I am recommending the one from E3D for it's great durability.
  • You adjust your Idler 1 time and then use the Birdey to Lock in and release the Idler. Removing the need to readjust the Idler every time you have to release it.
  • You can use normal Nema 17 or Nema 17 Pancake. It should have enough power for the pancake versions (please let me know if you test)
  • Can take Flexible filaments - not tested much yet - please give feedback

I have included 3 different Idlers:

  1. 1 which fits your old 8mm rod if you have an old Gregs extruder.
  2. 1 for 1x m3 20mm screw + small rod to fit in the bearing.
  3. 1 for a 1x m325mm screw + small rod to fit in the bearing.

*Adapters included/coming up

  • E3D Groove Mount
  • UM Bowden
  • Push-fitting with M6 threadding

BOM

  • 3x 608zz bearings. (2x for extruder 1x for idler)
  • 4x m3 12mm screws
  • 9x m3 nuts
  • 1x GT2-pulley 16 or 20 teeth.
  • 1x GT2-pulley 40 or 60 teeth.
  • 1x 8mm Hobbed Bolt - I used the Hobb-Goblin - 8mm Hobbed Shaft Kit as I had one lying around.
  • 1x 20mm or 25mm 3M screw or a piece of 8mm rod for the Idler.

Birdey Idler fastener:

  • 2x m3 50mm or longer screws
  • 2x 1cm or longer springs, matching the long screws.
  • 4x m3 spacers for the long screws and springs

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 or 0.25

Infill:

20

Notes:

I have printed at both 0.2 layers and 0.25 and both works fine but you might be able to see it visually.

Used 0,4mm nozzle with 2 perimeters and 0.6mm top/bottom.

Filament clearance Make sure the filament can run through freely

The hole is 3.2mm in the model, but will be less after printing. If you use 3mm you need to run a 3-3.2mm drill thrifty it.
If you use 2.85mm filament it might or
might not need some smoothing over. Depending on your printer.

Carefull not to enlarge it too much.

Prepare the Idler. Insert 3 m3 nuts and make sure the centre spacer fits snugly in the 608zz bearing. Prepare the Idler. Insert 2x m3 nuts. Use your 8mm rod through the bearing.

Calculate steps and gear ratio

Source is Triffid Hunter's Calibration Guide

Formular
e_steps_per_mm = (motor_steps_per_rev x driver_microstep) x (big_gear_teeth / small_gear_teeth) / (hob_effective_diameter x pi)

Gear ratio aluminium pulleys, common sizes
I have not tested with belts for all these configurations.

  • 16-GT2/60-GT2 aluminium pulleys: ratio 3,75:1
  • 20-GT2/60-GT2 aluminium pulleys: ratio 3:1
  • 16-GT2/40-GT2 aluminium pulleys: ratio 2,5:1
  • 20-GT2/40-GT2 aluminium pulleys: ratio 2:1
  • 16-GT2/36-GT2 aluminium pulleys: ratio 2:1
  • 20-GT2/36-GT2 aluminium pulleys.: ratio 1:8

Explanation

  • 200 = standard 1.8degree nema steps pr round
  • 16 = Multistepping
  • 60 = Size of the big pulley.
  • 20 = Size of the smaller pulley. 16 or 20
  • (7 * 3,14159) = Hobbed bolt effective diameter * pi = Normally 21,99113

Ratio of gears and steps/mm

Ratio of gears and steps/mm

Listed steps/mm is for 1:32 microstepping. Divide by 2 for 1:16 microstepping

  • 16-GT2/60-GT2 aluminium pulleys: ratio 3,75:1 - 1125 steps/mm
  • 20-GT2/60-GT2 aluminium pulleys: ratio 3:1 - 900 steps/mm
  • 16-GT2/40-GT2 aluminium pulleys: ratio 2,5:1 - 750 steps/mm
  • 20-GT2/40-GT2 aluminium pulleys: ratio 2:1 - 600 steps/mm
  • 16-GT2/36-GT2 aluminium pulleys: ratio 2:1 - 600 steps/mm
  • 20-GT2/36-GT2 aluminium pulleys.: ratio 1:8:1 - 540 steps/mm

If you use 1/16 multistepping, you just halve the steps/mm.

Ratio is really just calculated by doing a simple division of the larger and smaller gears (ie: 80/20 = ratio of 4:1).

Steps/mm is calculated using standard 1.8 degree nema motor (200 steps pr revolution). If you use 0.9 degree motor, you double it.

Update section

Update 04-06-2016

Removed last vestiges of printed wheels.
Found a Recommended gear and belt combo
I have also tested and used 16-GT2 and 60-GT2 Pulley without pulley with a 172-GT2 6mm belt.
Working on redrawing my extruder in Fusion 360 for easier manipulation.

Update 19-05-2016

Finally found the right combination of pulley and belt sizes to get rid of the large printed gear.
I am now using a 16-GT2 and 60-GT2 pulley along with a small idler and a 180-GT2 6mm belt.

Update29-94-2016

Had forgotten to update the crossbar for the birdnose: Birdeye_shaft.stl which is now to be found in Thing files.

Update 25-04-2016

  • I have been testing it a some this weekend and am very pleased!
  • It takes in filament without having to do anything and Works very well so far at rather low amperage where motor stayed cool.
  • Used it for a 5 hour printjob and a couple of small ones.
  • I have added a section for Steps/mm and ratio farther Down.
  • I have ordered an aluminium 60-GT2 Wheel I'll try to use. Should be plenty big and more accurate.
60-GT2 and 16-GT2 with a 172-GT2 belt. No idler needed.
